6:44 I wrapped my head around it by considering active vs passive transformations.

- As an active transformation, the matrix maps every vector in our coordinate system, to the corresponding vectors of Jennifer's system, without changing our point of view, so our coordinate system stays constant. The entire grid of vectors has changed on its own, thus the name 'active' transformation. It's like moving an object you're filming without changing the position of an camera.

- As a passive transformation, we're changing our point of view backwards, from Jennifer's to our coordinate system, so we're kind of translating everything described in Jennifer's language to our language, without changing the true position of vectors. You can think of it as moving the camera itself while not touching the object.

No matter in which way you view the transformation, the math behind it stays pretty much the same. And also I think it'd be a lot easier for us to grasp the 'backwards' phenomenon if you could introduce the above in the video.

Consider a Linear transformation T2  -> T2 such that T(<1, -1>) = <2,3> and T(<0, 1>) = <4,5>.       (the vectors are written as column vectors)


The question is to find the transformation matrix (say A).  We could add the transformation (since it is linear) to get the T(<1,0>) = <6,8>. We already have the T(<0,1>) = <4, 5>.

 So the matrix A = [<6,8>  <4,5>].


 Suppose we go the hard way and use the change of basis to figure out the transformation in standard basis.

So,  basis B becomes {<1, -1>  <0,1> }. And our change of basis matrix C becomes [<1, -1>  <0,1>]

Following that, our transformation matrix (in new coordinates) becomes D = [<2,3> <4,5>].


Now if we use just the formula  A = C D C(inv), (where C(inv) is the inverse of C),  we don't get to the right matrix !

Also if we just use the matrix multiplication  D C(inv), we get to the right matrix, but in that case we are not in the standard basis !

One way is as a linear transformation operator which moves a vector in standard basis to another vector in standard basis. Visually, this is what the previous videos have been showing, that the grid stays the same while the vector moves. The second way is as a change of basis operator, where the vector does not move, but the grid changes. 11:00 requires both views to make sense, and an understanding that the rightmost vector of [-1,2] is not in terms of the usual standard basis, but starting from jennifer's basis.

If we didn't know this matrix was the inverse of a previous transformation, and simply seen it as any other 2x2 transform, the animation would then be starting from the standard grid and rotating it rightwards, with a [3,2] vector becoming [5/3,1/3]. I think this explanation is neat, but it adds an unnecessary complication.

The change of basis matrix as defined in the video translates the new language into the old one, or rather expresses the new basis B' from the point of view of the old one, B. For simplicity, let's call this matrix M(B'→B). Also, let's denote the representation of a vector v in a basis B as [v]B.

Instead of thinking of applying this matrix to the "misconception" of the vector v in our grid, think of applying it directly to Jennifer's version of the vector - so that one obtains the simple formula

[v]B = M(B'→B) [v]B'.

No need to be confused about the geometric vs numerical interpretation of the transformation.

Of course, in many textbooks the change of basis matrix is actually the inverse of M(B'→B), that is, M(B→B'), as we usually prefer to think of a change of basis as a shift into a new perspective rather than a need of translating another language.
